Description.val:
Submarine Life Support System procures Low Pressure Electrolyzer (LPE) oxygen generators to fulfill the Program of Record requirement to replace the legacy obsolete high pressure Electrolytic Oxygen Generator (EOG) on SSBNs.  The LPE is critical to the OHIO Class to achieve service life extension to 42 years. Procurements are tied to specific submarine availabilities since a major ship alteration is required for installation.

[P40A / SUBMARINE LIFE SUPPORT SYSTEM]: 5D830 - PRODUCTION ENGINEERING The review and approval of any production contract technical documentation, or the separate development of this documentation to include, technical manuals, Preventive Maintenance Schedule, Level III production drawings, Provisioning Technical Documentation, Program Support Data and Allowance Parts Lists; Engineering & support for final design reviews.  This work can be accomplished by NSWC PHILA as the in-service engineering agent, other Naval activities or contractors as appropriate.
Design and Development: Funding to support the necessary Design and Development efforts to address required modernization changes to the Submarine Life Support Systems. This funding will start the design and development efforts for the Central Atmosphere Monitoring System (CAMS) sustainment for VIRGINIA Class blocks I and II via upgrade, achieving commonality with later VA Class blocks and with COLUMBIA and LOS ANGELES Class. This alteration provides sustainable capability for atmosphere monitoring on VA Class submarines with improved parts support for atmosphere monitoring on OHIO and SEAWOLF Class.

[P3A - 2 / LOW PRESSURE ELECTROLYZER]: 5D010 - THE LOW PRESSURE ELECTROLYZER (LPE) The LPE will replace the EOG currently being used on SSBN/SSGN Class submarines. The LPE produces oxygen at low pressure, eliminating the need for high pressure oxygen storage. There will be two LPEs on each SSBN/SSGN Class submarine. EOG's must be replaced by LPE's on OHIO SSBNs to ensure they can sustain current operational availability requirements through their 42 yr service life. Oxygen Generators are necessary to maintain submarine stealth while on mission. Therefore, procurements are driven by the OHIO Class maintenance period schedule. The replacement of the EOG with the LPE must be done during a major maintenance availability due to the time to complete the installation. As OHIO Class submarine approach the end of service life there are fewer major maintenance periods remaining, increasing the number of concurrent procurements required. Differences in unit costs above inflation are due to the number of units being procured each fiscal year. Unit costs are impacted by quantities of scale.

Justification.val:
Contract used to procure LPEs was awarded in FY16.  This is a five-year fixed price contract to achieve a better price with higher quantity orders. LPE units orders are timed to support LPE installations during a refit that supports extending the service life of the submarine. Installations are also aligned when current oxygen generators would receive required replacement of cells which are necessary for continued operation of legacy oxygen generators, thus avoiding an approximate $2M/ship additional maintenance cost.  Funding decrease in FY21 and increase in FY22 through FY25 are due to realigning the procurement and installation of Low Pressure Electrolyzers (LPEs) on OHIO Class submarines to one per year to coincide with availability schedules. Provides a steady and executable funding profile for LPEs as the existing Electrolytic Oxygen Generators (EOGs) have parts obsolescence and increased risk of at-sea failures.

Additionally, BLI 0990 is for all Submarine Life Support Systems, including Central Atmospheric Monitoring System (CAMS), Diesel Exhaust, Electro Oxygen Generators (EOG), Automatic Electro-Oxygen Generators (AEOG), Oxygen Concentration (SAROS), other oxygen generators (ILPE, AILPE, LPE), CO2 Scrubbers, and Burners.  Starting in FY20, there is sufficient funding to begin design and development of Modernization of CAMS, as discussed in the second paragraph in Page 1 of the P-40.  As more obsolescence requires redesign, the funds in this very specific BLI will be applied to the above systems to ensure Submarine Atmosphere Control systems meet the needs of the fleet.  BLI 0990 supports level loaded funding for obsolescence management as agreed upon with N97 resource sponsor.  For example, CAMS sustainment for Blocks 1 and 2 is requested to convert legacy CAMS units by replacing the A5 module with CAMS modules used on a later VIRGINIA Class block design.  The legacy A5 module unit is the heart of CAMS, containing a ruggedized mass spectrometer requiring periodic replacement and overhaul.  The A5 modules used in legacy CAMS (blocks 1 and 2) are no longer manufactured by vendors and spares are limited, so without redesign & development, the system is not supportable for the life cycle of the platform.

Name.@footnote: Current LPE procurement contract expires in FY21.  A new contract will be competed and initial first article unit will be ordered.  Estimated contract award mid FY22, manufacture time 15 months plus 3 months of qualification unit. Unit requires refurbishment after qualification testing.   Second unit will be ordered after qualification testing in FY24 with expected install of units in FY25.  Final two units procured in FY25, with expected delivery in FY26.    Additionally, funding for the 688 Class LPEs: Procure 1 LPE in FY19 for installation in FY21, procure 1 LPE in FY21 for installation in FY23, procure 1 LPE in FY22 for installation in FY24, procure 1 LPE in FY24 for installation in FY26, procure 2 LPEs in FY25 for installation in FY27, and procure 1 LPE in FY26 for installation in FY28.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Method:: Installation Name: Installation Group Name

Description.val:
[LOW PRESSURE ELECTROLYZER] The LPE will replace the EOG currently being used on SSBN/SSGN Class submarines. The LPE produces oxygen at low pressure, eliminating the need for high pressure oxygen storage. There will be two LPEs on each SSBN/SSGN Class submarine. EOG's must be replaced by LPE's on OHIO SSBNs to ensure they can sustain current operational availability requirements through their 42 yr service life. Oxygen Generators are necessary to maintain submarine stealth while on mission. Therefore, procurements are driven by the OHIO Class maintenance period schedule. The replacement of the EOG with the LPE must be done during a major maintenance availability due to the time to complete the installation. As OHIO Class submarine approach the end of service life there are fewer major maintenance periods remaining, increasing the number of concurrent procurements required. Differences in unit costs above inflation are due to the number of units being procured each fiscal year. Unit costs are impacted by quantities of scale. 
Increased funding to install Low Pressure Electrolyzer (LPE) on 7 SSN 688I submarines planned for ERO/life extension. Current 688 Class Electrolytic Oxygen Generators (AEOGs) are not sustainable for planned extended life of above 7 hulls.  AEOGs are 1960s technology, not fully supported, and use costly, hazardous materials operating at high pressures. LPEs are common to OHIO, VIRGINA and SEAWOLF Class and are supportable for life of refueled 688s.
